file

The descriptor for the file attribute on the model instance. Return a FieldFile when accessed so you can write code like:

>>> from myapp.models import MyModel
>>> instance = MyModel.objects.get(pk=1)
>>> instance.file.size

Assign a file object on assignment so you can do:

>>> with open('/path/to/hello.world') as f:
...     instance.file = File(f)

booking.serializers module

This module contains serializer classes for the booking app.

class:TicketQuantityClassSerializer: Serializer class to return the quantity tickets sold out of the capacity(total).

class:DashboardOrderItemSerializer: Serializer class to return the attendee report.

booking.tests module

booking.urls module

booking.views module

This module contains several function based views for the booking app. function:list_ticket_classes_by_event: A FBV thst Return a list of all ticket classes for a given event. function:check_promo_code: A FBV Check whether a promo code is valid for a given event. function:create_order: A FBV that create order with its order items and Return the data saved. function:confirm_order: a FBV that confirms the order by the sent token to user’s email. function:list_orders_by_user : a FBV that returns orders by user id. function:list_orderitem_by_order : a FBV that return order items in an order by order id. function:list_orderitem_by_user : a FBV that returns order items by user id.

booking.views.check_promocode(request, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Check whether a promocode is valid for a given event.

Parameters:

  • request – HTTP request object.

  • event_id – Event ID.

Returns:

A JSON object indicating whether the promo code is valid.

booking.views.confirm_order(request, *args, **kwargs)[source]

This function confirms an order by taking a token as input and returning a response indicating whether the order has been validated. The token is used to retrieve the order ID, which is then used to update the order object’s is_validated field to True. The function returns a response with the value of is_validated as True and a status code of 200 if successful.

booking.views.create_order(request, *args, **kwargs)[source]

This view creates an order for an event with the specified event ID. user ID are received in the request data. A discount code may also be included. request data should look like this

{

“order_items”: [

{ “ticket_class_id” : 1, “quantity”: 3 }, { “ticket_class_id” : 2, “quantity”: 1 }

], “promocode” : “DISCOUNT25” // optional

}

booking.views.list_orderitem_by_order(request, *args, **kwargs)[source]
booking.views.list_orderitem_by_user(request, *args, **kwargs)[source]

This function takes a user_id as input and returns a list of OrderItem objects associated with the given user. It uses the OrderItemSerializer to serialize the data before returning it in the response.

booking.views.list_orders_by_user(request, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Return a list of all orders for a given user.

Parameters:

  • request – HTTP request object.

  • user_id – User ID.

Returns:

A list of JSON objects representing the bookings for the given user.

booking.views.list_ticket_classes_by_event(request, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Return a list of all ticket class for a given event.

Parameters:

  • request – HTTP request object.

  • event_id – Event ID.

Returns:

A list of JSON objects representing the bookings for the given event.

booking.views.quantity_sold_out_of_total(request, *args, **kwargs)[source]

A view function that returns the ticket classes ids in an event associated with how many tickets were sold out of the total. It uses the TicketQuantityClassSerializer to serialize the data before returning it in the response.

booking.views.send_confirmation_email(request, order)[source]

This function should construct the url with a token and send the link by mail to the user
